en.hero_title: Live the best experiences in Colombia
en.hero_description: Discover the magic of Colombia, a destination that has it all: paradisiacal beaches, imposing mountains, lush jungles and vibrant cities. From historic Cartagena to modern Bogot√°, every corner offers a unique experience. Enjoy its rich culture, delicious gastronomy and the warmth of its people. Colombia awaits you with open arms for unforgettable adventures!
en.card1_description: A Tayrona archaeological treasure in the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. More than 200 ancient terraces surrounded by jungle, history and indigenous culture.
en.card2_description: The "river of five colors" in La Macarena. A unique natural spectacle, where aquatic plants paint the water with shades of red, green, yellow and blue.
en.card3_description: Colonial charm in Boyac√°. Cobblestone streets, Colombia's largest square and a journey back in time through history, art and nature.
en.card4_description: Magic between desert and Caribbean Sea. Home of the Wayuu people, golden dunes, virgin beaches and breathtaking landscapes.
en.history_text: Colombia has a rich history dating back thousands of years before the arrival of the Spanish in the 16th century. Originally inhabited by diverse indigenous cultures such as the Muiscas, Taironas and Quimbayas, the region was colonized by Spain in 1499. During the colonial period, Colombia was part of the Viceroyalty of Peru and later the Viceroyalty of New Granada. In 1810, Colombia began its struggle for independence, which culminated in 1819 under the leadership of Sim√≥n Bol√≠var. After independence, Colombia went through several political and territorial changes, including the formation of Gran Colombia, which included Venezuela, Ecuador and Panama. In the 20th century, Colombia faced significant challenges such as internal armed conflicts and drug trafficking-related problems. However, in recent decades, the country has worked to overcome these challenges and has experienced economic growth and greater political stability. Today, Colombia is a vibrant nation with a unique blend of indigenous, Spanish and African traditions.
en.gastronomy_text: Colombian gastronomy is a delicious fusion of indigenous, Spanish and African flavors, reflecting the country's cultural diversity. Each region has its own culinary specialties, from arepa and sancocho on the Caribbean coast to ajiaco in Bogot√° and bandeja paisa in Antioquia. Fresh ingredients such as corn, yuca, plantain, beans and a variety of meats and fish are fundamental in Colombian cuisine. Iconic dishes such as ceviche, empanadas, tamal and rice with coconut are just some of the delights that visitors can enjoy. In addition, Colombia is famous for its high-quality coffee, considered one of the best in the world. Colombian gastronomy not only satisfies the palate, but also offers a unique cultural experience that invites you to explore the country's traditions and customs.
en.culture_text: Colombian culture is a vibrant mosaic of traditions, customs and artistic expressions that reflect the country's ethnic and geographic diversity. Influenced by indigenous, Spanish and African cultures, Colombian culture manifests itself in its music, dance, literature and festivals. Rhythms such as cumbia, vallenato and salsa are emblematic, while festivals such as the Barranquilla Carnival and the Flower Fair in Medell√≠n celebrate the joy and color of Colombian life. Colombian literature has produced world-renowned figures such as Gabriel Garc√≠a M√°rquez, whose magical realism has captured the essence of the country. In addition, gastronomy, crafts and family traditions play a crucial role in Colombia's cultural identity. Together, Colombian culture is a continuous celebration of its rich heritage and resilient spirit.

en.exp1_title: Whale Watching in Buenaventura: A Marine Ballet in the Colombian Pacific
en.exp1_text: Every year, between July and October, the coasts of Buenaventura become the stage for one of the most moving natural spectacles on the planet: humpback whale watching. These ocean giants migrate from Antarctica to give birth and care for their calves in the warm waters of the Colombian Pacific. From local boats, visitors can observe jumps, tail slaps and songs that shake the soul. It is an experience that combines science, culture and emotion, framed by the humid jungle and the resilient spirit of the Afro-Colombian communities that guide this journey.
en.exp2_title: Cartagena Walls: The Stone Embrace that Protects History
en.exp2_text: The walls of Cartagena de Indias, built between the 16th and 18th centuries, are much more than a fortress: they are the living testimony of a city that resisted pirates, empires and the passage of time. This defensive system, composed of bastions, bulwarks and forts, surrounds the historic center like a stone embrace that protects colonial squares, baroque churches and colorful alleys. Walking along its walls at sunset is to travel through centuries of history while the Caribbean breeze caresses the soul.
en.exp3_title: Tayrona Park: Where the Sierra Meets the Sea
en.exp3_text: Located on the northern coast of Colombia, Tayrona National Natural Park is a sanctuary of biodiversity and spirituality. In its more than 150 km¬≤, the tropical jungle descends from the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta to embrace golden sand beaches and turquoise waters. This ancestral territory, sacred to indigenous peoples such as the Kogi and Arhuacos, offers trails that connect mangroves, reefs, archaeological ruins and natural viewpoints. Walking through Tayrona is immersing yourself in a dialogue between mountain and sea, between the visible and the invisible, where every stone and every wave tells a story.
en.arq_place1_desc: In the highest coastal mountain in the world, there is Teyuna or the Lost City of the Tayrona, over 1,500 years old. This city consists of 35 hectares where ceremonial complexes can be seen
en.arq_place2_desc: üóø The Archaeological Park of Monquir√°, Boyac√°, is a territory that belonged to the Muiscas about 2,500 years ago and has a series of monolithic sculptures up to five meters high, made in pre-Hispanic times. en.arq_place4_desc: Located a few minutes from Lake Calima, travelers can learn more about the Amerindian cultures that inhabited Valle del Cauca before the Spanish conquest, with an exhibition of around 1,800 pieces belonging to this ancestral culture.
en.cul_place1_desc: La Guajira is a unique region in the extreme north of Colombia, where the desert meets the Caribbean Sea in a landscape of harsh beauty and intense contrasts. Its territory ranges from the golden dunes of Cabo de la Vela to the green mountains of the Serran√≠a de Macuira, an oasis of biodiversity in the middle of aridity. It is the ancestral home of the Way√∫u people, whose culture, language and traditions remain alive and deeply rooted in daily life.
en.cul_place2_desc: The Muiscas were a highly organized civilization that inhabited the Andean highlands in the current departments of Cundinamarca and Boyac√°. Their society was ruled by two leaders: the Zipa and the Zaque. They excelled in agriculture, salt mining and gold goldsmithing, with pieces that inspired the myth of El Dorado. Their worldview revolved around the sun, moon and cycles of nature.

en.cul_place3_desc: The Arhuacos inhabit the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, considered by them as the Heart of the World. Their spirituality is deeply linked to the balance of nature, and their spiritual leaders, the Mamos, guide the community in practices of harmony with the earth. They dress in white as a symbol of purity, and their woven bags represent maps of the universe.
en.cul_place4_title: Zen√∫es Sin√∫ and San Jorge Valley
en.cul_place4_desc: The Zen√∫es were masters in hydraulic engineering, creating systems of channels and ridges to cultivate in floodable areas of the Colombian Caribbean. Their culture revolved around water, mud and tropical vegetation. They are the creators of the iconic vueltiao hat, a national symbol of Colombia.
en.gas_place1_desc: Bandeja Paisa is a traditional meal from the Paisa region of Colombia, which includes the cities of Medell√≠n, Santa Fe de Antioquia, Guatape and Jard√≠n. In fact, it is so beloved that it has been adopted as the national dish of Colombia. This abundant meal usually contains white rice, red beans, ground or chopped meat, plantain, chorizo, corn, pork cracklings, fried egg, arepa and an avocado.
en.gas_place2_desc: Pandebono is a traditional bread originating from the Valle del Cauca region in Colombia, made with corn flour, cassava starch, cheese and egg, and occasionally served with guava paste. Pandebono can be enjoyed in many bakeries throughout the country.
en.gas_place3_desc: Hen sancocho is one of the most traditional and comforting dishes of Colombian gastronomy, especially popular in regions such as Valle del Cauca. It is a thick and tasty soup, prepared with creole hen, which provides a more intense flavor than conventional chicken.
en.gas_place4_desc: Lechona is an emblematic dish of Colombian gastronomy, especially associated with Tolima, although it is enjoyed in many regions of the country. It is a festive, abundant and slow-cooked preparation, ideal for celebrations and family gatherings.
en.nat_place1_title: The Coffee Cultural Landscape of Colombia
en.nat_place1_desc: ‚òï Coffee Region (Eje Cafetero): Nestled in the central Andes of Colombia, it was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 2011. Its landscape combines coffee plantations, colorful towns, yipaos, chivas and a warm hospitality that reflect the Colombian essence. Colonized in the 18th century by people from Antioquia after the decline of gold, the region became the epicenter of arabica coffee, considered one of the best in the world. In addition to its crops, it offers exuberant biodiversity with orchids, hummingbirds, p√°ramos, thermal springs and the emblematic wax palms, a national symbol.
en.nat_place2_desc: One of the most varied parks in Colombia, where we can observe much of the area's fauna and a great variety of flora, full of trails for hiking and many recreational activities. In addition to this, you can meet and live with tribes that still have settlements in the Park. Inside the park we find the most beautiful river in the world ¬´Ca√±o Cristales¬ª, also known as the River of 5 colors, beautiful for its crystal clear waters and for the strange vegetation that grows in it, which is responsible for giving those beautiful colors that enhance the beauty of this river.
en.nat_place3_desc: ‚õ∞Ô∏è Its landscape is very diverse, made up of snow-capped mountains, lagoons, streams and the green of the mountains. It can be reached from Bogot√°, Bucaramanga and the Eastern Plains. This NNP is ideal for hiking and climbing as well as bird watching and landscape photography activities.
en.nat_place4_desc: üå¥ Its majestic sea attracts thousands of tourists daily who wish to enjoy it and all the biodiversity that this NNP offers. Blue waters, white sand, forest, fauna and flora and its charming view of the largest snow-capped mountain range in the world on the seashore. It can be reached from Santa Marta and from Guajira by the Troncal del Caribe highway. Inside the park you can find accommodation in cabins or you can camp. You will also find important archaeological remains of the ancient inhabitants of Tayrona.
en.pat_place1_title: Historic Center of Santa Cruz de Mompox
en.pat_place1_desc: üìç Santa Cruz de Mompox, located in the Colombian Caribbean savannah, was declared a Cultural and Religious Heritage of Humanity by UNESCO in 1995. Founded in 1537 on the banks of the Magdalena River, it preserves its intact colonial architecture and is surrounded by swamps. It is recognized for its impressive Holy Week processions, its link to the literary universe of Gabriel Garc√≠a M√°rquez and for being the birthplace of singer Toto la Momposina. Its economy is based on goldsmithing, fishing and tourism that is still not very mass, which makes it an authentic and out of the ordinary destination.
en.pat_place2_desc: üóø San Agust√≠n, located in southern Colombia in the heart of the Andes mountain range, was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1995. It is the largest archaeological site in the country, famous for more than 500 majestic stone statues carved by an ancestral civilization without a written language. Surrounded by Andean landscapes, cobblestone paths and burial mounds, San Agust√≠n is a unique destination that combines mystery, pre-Hispanic art and natural beauty.
en.pat_place3_desc: ‚õ∞Ô∏è Tierradentro, located north of San Agust√≠n, was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1995. This archaeological site stands out for its underground tombs excavated by the Paeces indigenous people, decorated with geometric figures in white, red and black. Nestled among mountains and canyons, the difficult terrain allowed the Paeces to resist conquest and preserve their culture, which still lives on in their descendants. Among the most visited places are El Aguacate, San Andr√©s de Pisimbal√°, Alto San Andr√©s and Alto de Segovia, all witnesses to the Colombian pre-Columbian legacy.
en.pat_place4_title: Port, Fortresses and Monumental Complex of Cartagena
en.pat_place4_desc: üå¥ Cartagena, founded in 1533 by Pedro de Heredia, is a colonial jewel of the Colombian Caribbean. Its historic center, protected by a wall against pirates, was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1984. With its colonial houses, aromatic streets and sea breeze, Cartagena is considered the most beautiful colonial city in South America. Its warm and colorful nights make it perfect for those seeking a romantic destination full of history.
